gr.forth.ics.graph.event
Class WeakListener

java.lang.Object
  gr.forth.ics.graph.event.WeakListener
All Implemented Interfaces:
EdgeListener, GraphListener, NodeListener, OperationListener, EventListener
public final class WeakListener
extends Object
implements GraphListener

A graph listener with a corresponing delegate listener (which actually processes all graph events), which does not prevent the latter of being reclaimed by the garbage collector. This class offers a safe way to create listeners to graph that update external structures in response to graph modifications, without making such listeners the source of memory leaks; note that a graph strongly references its current list of listeners, so if a normal listener is attached to a graph, it cannot be reclaimed (nor whatever it references) before the graph itself is reclaimed, even if it is unreachable from anywhere else.

A WeakListener automatically deregisters itself from a graph when it finds that the delegate listener is garbage collected.

Method Detail

createAndAttach

public static WeakListener createAndAttach(InspectableGraph graph,
                                           GraphListener delegateListener)
Creates a WeakListener and attaches it to a graph. The WeakListener delegates all events it receives to a specified listener. It will not prevent the specified listener from being garbage collected, i.e. it does not strongly reference it. The WeakListener will automatically remove itself from the graph when the delegate listener is garbage collected.

If you create a structure that needs to update itself dynamically by responding to graph events, but you want the structure itself to be reclaimable before the graph (simply by removing references to it), you need to use a WeakListener to receive the events. That is because directly registering a listener to a graph creates a strong reference to it, thus the graph indirectly strongly references the structure, so it cannot be reclaimed unless the listener is explicitly removed from the graph. Using a WeakListener does not require explicitly removing it from the graph.

It is guaranteed that the delegate listener cannot be garbage collected during a graph event processing.

Parameters:
graph - the graph the events of which the listener is interested in
delegateListener - the listener that will handle the events coming from the specified graph
